title: Joseph Weigl
text:
Joseph Weigl (28 March 1766 – 3 February 1846) was an <a href="Austria">Austria</a>n <a href="composer">composer</a> and <a href="conducting">conductor</a>, born in <a href="Eisenstadt">Eisenstadt</a>, <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Hungary">Hungary</a>, <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian Empire</a>.
The son of <a href="Joseph%20Franz%20Weigl">Joseph Franz Weigl</a> (1740–1820), the principal <a href="cellist">cellist</a> in the <a href="orchestra">orchestra</a> of the <a href="House%20of%20Esterh%C3%A1zy">Esterházy</a> family, he studied music under <a href="Johann%20Georg%20Albrechtsberger">Johann Georg Albrechtsberger</a> <a href="Wolfgang%20Amadeus%20Mozart">Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart</a> and <a href="Antonio%20Salieri">Antonio Salieri</a>. He became <a href="Kapellmeister">Kapellmeister</a> at the <a href="court%20theatre">court theatre</a> in <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a> in 1792, and from 1827 to 1838 was vice-Kapellmeister of the court.
Weigl composed a number of <a href="opera">opera</a>s, both Italian and German and in various genres, although most of his late works are pieces of sacred music. His best known work was the opera "<a href="Die%20Schweizerfamilie">Die Schweizerfamilie</a>" (1809). He also set <a href="Emanuel%20Schikaneder">Emanuel Schikaneder</a>'s libretto "<a href="Vestas%20Feuer">Vestas Feuer</a>" (1805), after his close friend <a href="Ludwig%20van%20Beethoven">Ludwig van Beethoven</a> had composed a single scene and then abandoned it.
He died in Vienna.
